meta.dc:subject: legislation
meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: An Ordinance to incorporate the existing Independent Police Complaints Council; to provide for the Council’s functions in monitoring the handling and investigation of reportable complaints by the Commissioner of Police; to provide for the Council’s powers relating to its affairs and operation; to provide for the appointment of observers in relation to reportable complaints; and to provide for connected matters.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Independent Police Complaints Council Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: appointed member (委任成員) means a member of the Council referred to in section 5(1)(c), and includes a person appointed under section 5 of Schedule 1 to act as an appointed member;

def.name: Categorization
def.leadIn: categorization (歸類) means the categorization by the Commissioner of a complaint as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reportable complaint; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a notifiable complaint;

subsection.def: Chairman (主席) means the Chairman of the Council referred to in section 5(1)(a), and includes a person appointed under section 5 of Schedule 1 to act as the Chairman;

def.name: Classification
def.leadIn: classification (分類) means the classification after investigation by the Commissioner of a reportable complaint as one that is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: substantiated;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: substantiated other than reported;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not fully substantiated;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: unsubstantiated;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: false;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: no fault;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: withdrawn;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: not pursuable;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: curtailed;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: informally resolved; or

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: of such other description as agreed between the Council and the Commissioner;

subsection.def: Commissioner (處長) means the Commissioner of Police;

complainant (投訴人) means a person who makes a complaint or a request for review or, where the complaint or request for review is made on behalf of another person, the person on whose behalf the complaint or request for review is made;
function (職能) includes a power and a duty;
Legal Adviser (法律顧問) means the Legal Adviser to the Council appointed under section 6(1);
member of the police force (警隊成員) includes a public officer attached to the police force;
mentally incapacitated person (精神上無行為能力的人) means a person who is mentally disordered or mentally handicapped within the meaning of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136);
notifiable complaint (須知會投訴) means a complaint categorized as a notifiable complaint in accordance with section 14;
police conduct (警方行為) means the conduct, practice or procedure referred to in section 11(a);
police force (警隊) means the Hong Kong Police Force or the Hong Kong Auxiliary Police Force established under the Hong Kong Auxiliary Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 233);

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a complaint categorized as a reportable complaint in accordance with section 11; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a request for review treated as a reportable complaint in accordance with section 13;

subsection.def: request for review (覆核要求) means a request for reviewing the classification of a reportable complaint referred to in section 13;
Vice-Chairman (副主席) means a Vice-Chairman of the Council referred to in section 5(1)(b), and includes a person appointed under section 5 of Schedule 1 to act as a Vice-Chairman.

subsection.content: In this Ordinance, a reference to the performance of a function includes the exercise of a power and the discharge of a duty.

In sections 8(1)(b), 19(1)(d), 26 and 40(3)(b), a reference to any action taken or to be taken in respect of a member of the police force includes a decision that no action be taken against that member.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Incorporation of Independent Police Complaints Council

subsection.leadIn: There is hereby established a body corporate known as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: “Independent Police Complaints Council” in English; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: “獨立監察警方處理投訴委員會” in Chinese.

subsection.content: The Council has perpetual succession and may sue and be sued in its English or Chinese name.
The Council is neither a servant nor an agent of the Government and does not enjoy any status, immunity or privilege of the Government.

subsection.leadIn: The Council consists of the following members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Chairman appointed by the Chief Executive;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 3 Vice-Chairmen appointed by the Chief Executive; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not less than 8 other members appointed by the Chief Executive.

subsection.leadIn: The following persons are not eligible for appointment under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who holds an office of emolument, whether permanent or temporary, in a Government bureau or department; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who was a member of the police force.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Appointment of Secretary-General, Legal Adviser and other employees

subsection.content: The Council must appoint a Secretary-General and a Legal Adviser on terms of employment approved by the Chief Executive on the advice of the Council.
The Council may appoint, on terms of employment determined by the Council, such other employees as the Council requires to assist it in performing its functions.
The Council may engage any person for his technical or professional services in such manner and on such terms as it thinks fit.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Schedule 1 applicable to Council
section.content: Schedule 1 has effect with respect to the members, proceedings, committees and finances of, and the execution of documents by, and other miscellaneous matters of, the Council.

subsection.leadIn: The functions of the Council are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to observe, monitor and review the handling and investigation of reportable complaints by the Commissioner, and to make recommendations (as the Council considers appropriate) to the Commissioner or the Chief Executive or both of them in respect of the handling or investigation of reportable complaints;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to monitor actions taken or to be taken in respect of any member of the police force by the Commissioner in connection with reportable complaints, and to advise (as the Council considers appropriate) the Commissioner or the Chief Executive or both of them of its opinion on such actions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to identify any fault or deficiency in any practice or procedure adopted by the police force that has led to or might lead to reportable complaints, and to make recommendations (as the Council considers appropriate) to the Commissioner or the Chief Executive or both of them in respect of such practice or procedure;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to review anything submitted to it by the Commissioner pursuant to this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to promote public awareness of the role of the Council; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: (without limiting the generality of the foregoing) any function conferred on it by or under this or any other Ordinance.

subsection.content: The Council may do all such things that are reasonably necessary for, or incidental or conducive to, the performance of its functions under this Ordinance.

division.name: D1
division.heading: Functions relating to Commissioner’s Categorization of Complaints

section.name: s9
section.heading: Commissioner to submit lists of complaints

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner must submit to the Council at such intervals, and in such manner, as the Commissioner and the Council may agree—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a list of reportable complaints; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a list of notifiable complaints.

subsection.content: A list submitted under subsection (1)(a) must include a brief description of all reportable complaints that the Commissioner has received since the end of the period covered by the last list so submitted.

subsection.leadIn: A list submitted under subsection (1)(b) must include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a brief description of all notifiable complaints that the Commissioner has received since the end of the period covered by the last list so submitted;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reasons for categorizing the complaints as notifiable complaints; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to a belated complaint (as defined in section 12(3)) that is not categorized as a reportable complaint solely on the ground that the complaint is not of a serious nature, the reasons supporting that ground.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Certain complaints not to be included in lists under section 9(1)
section.leadIn: A list under section 9(1)(a) or (b) must not include a complaint that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person makes in his official capacity as a member of the police force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arises from the issue of a summons and solely relates to the question of whether the summons is validly issued;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: arises from the issue of any notice for the imposition of a fixed penalty under any enactment and solely relates to the question of whether the notice is validly issued; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person is empowered to investigate pursuant to any function conferred on the person by any other Ordinance, except where the complaint relates to police conduct and the power of investigation does not extend to the investigation of that police conduct.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Complaints categorized as reportable complaints
section.leadIn: Subject to sections 10, 12 and 13, a complaint received by the Commissioner must be categorized as a reportable complaint if the complaint—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the conduct of a member of the police force while on duty or in the execution or purported execution of his duties, whether or not he identified himself as such a member;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the conduct of a member of the police force who identified himself as such a member while off duty; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: any practice or procedure adopted by the police force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not vexatious or frivolous and is made in good faith;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is made by or on behalf of a complainant directly affected by the police conduct;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: is made by a person (whether on his own behalf or on behalf of a complainant) who has properly identified himself and provided the Commissioner with a means of contacting him; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: (if made by a person on behalf of a complainant) is made in accordance with section 15.

subsection.content: Except as provided in subsection (2), a belated complaint must not be categorized as a reportable complaint.

subsection.leadIn: A belated complaint must be categorized as a reportable complaint if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is serious in nature; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: but for subsection (1), it would be categorized as a reportable complaint in accordance with section 11.

def.name: BelatedComplaint
def.leadIn: In this section, belated complaint (逾期投訴) means a complaint that is made to the Commissioner after the expiration of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 24 months from the date of the incident giving rise to the complaint; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (where proceedings relating to the subject matter of the complaint have been commenced in any court, magistracy or statutory tribunal within the period referred to in paragraph (a)) 12 months from the date of the final determination of such proceedings,

section.name: s13
section.heading: Requests for review treated as reportable complaints

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), a request for review made to the Commissioner for reviewing the classification of a reportable complaint (the relevant classification) is to be treated as a reportable complaint only if the request for review—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not vexatious or frivolous;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is made in good faith; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: (if made by a person on behalf of a complainant) is made in accordance with section 15.

subsection.content: A request for review must not seek for the review of a reportable complaint that is classified as “informally resolved”.

subsection.leadIn: On such review, the Commissioner is not required to conduct a fresh or further investigation of any fact or evidence considered in the determination of the relevant classification unless the person who makes the request for review puts forward a point of view on the analysis of that fact or evidence and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner did not consider such a point of view in his determination of the relevant classification;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the point of view, if established after a fresh or further investigation of that fact or evidence, may result in a change of the relevant classification; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the consideration of the point of view reasonably requires a fresh or further investigation of that fact or evidence.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Complaints categorized as notifiable complaints
section.content: A complaint received by the Commissioner must be categorized as a notifiable complaint if it is neither a reportable complaint nor a complaint referred to in section 10.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Making complaint or request for review on behalf of complainant

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, a person (the representative) may make a complaint or a request for review on behalf of a complainant only if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: the complainant is a mentally incapacitated person or is unable to make the complaint or request for review (as the case may be) himself due to death or illness, and the representative is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a relative of the complainant; or

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the representative has written authorization from the complainant to make the complaint or request for review (as the case may be) on behalf of the complainant.

def.name: Relative
def.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), relative (親屬) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a spouse, child, parent, grandparent or grandchild; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who is, or is the issue of, a brother, sister, uncle or aunt.

subsection.leadIn: In deducing any relationship for the purposes of subsections (1) and (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an adopted person is treated as the child of the person or persons by whom he was adopted;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any relationship by affinity is treated as a relationship by consanguinity, any relationship of the half blood as a relationship of the whole blood, and the step-child of a person as the child of that person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an illegitimate child is treated as a legitimate child of his mother and reputed father.

subsection.leadIn: If the Council considers that a complaint included in a list of notifiable complaints under section 9 should be categorized as a reportable complaint, it may advise the Commissioner of its opinion, and the Commissioner must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: have regard to such opinion; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reconsider the categorization of the complaint.

subsection.content: The Commissioner must, as soon as practicable after the completion of his reconsideration under subsection (1), inform the Council of the outcome of his reconsideration.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of performing the Council’s function under subsection (1), the Council may require the Commissioner to provide—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: explanations to support the categorization of a complaint as a notifiable complaint;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a belated complaint (as defined in section 12(3)) that is not categorized as a reportable complaint solely on the ground that the complaint is not of a serious nature, explanations to support that ground; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: information or material in support of the explanations.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Functions relating to Investigation or Interim Investigation Reports on Reportable Complaints

section.name: s17
section.heading: Commissioner to submit investigation reports on reportable complaints

subsection.content: The Commissioner must, as soon as practicable after completing the investigation of a reportable complaint, submit to the Council an investigation report.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), an investigation report submitted under subsection (1) must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a summary of the investigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a finding of facts in relation to the complaint and the evidence in support of the finding;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the classification of the complaint, and the reasons for the classification;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an account of the action taken or to be taken by the Commissioner in connection with the complaint;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: such information as the Commissioner thinks necessary; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: such other information as the Commissioner and the Council may agree.

subsection.leadIn: An investigation report on a reportable complaint classified as informally resolved must—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a summary of the process of informal resolution of the complaint;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an account of the incident giving rise to the complaint as described by the complainant;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: (if the complainee is identified) an account of the incident giving rise to the complaint as described by the complainee;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: an account of the action taken or to be taken by the Commissioner in connection with the complaint;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: such information as the Commissioner thinks necessary; and

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: such other information as the Commissioner and the Council may agree; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: explain the reasons for resolving the complaint by informal resolution.

subsection.content: In subsections (1) and (2), a reference to an investigation report includes an investigation report supplementary to a previous investigation report.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Commissioner to submit interim investigation reports on reportable complaints

subsection.leadIn: If the investigation of a reportable complaint is not completed within—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 6 months from the date of receipt of the complaint; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such shorter period as the Commissioner and the Council may agree,

subsection.continued: then, the Commissioner must, as soon as practicable after the expiry of those 6 months or that shorter period, submit to the Council an interim investigation report.

subsection.leadIn: Until the completion of the investigation, the Commissioner must submit to the Council further interim investigation reports after the expiry of every successive period of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such shorter period as the Commissioner and the Council may agree.

subsection.leadIn: An interim investigation report submitted under subsection (1) or (2) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contain a summary of the progress of the investigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: explain the reasons for not being able to complete the investigation within the 6 months’ period or such shorter period covered by the report.

subsection.content: The Council may advise the Commissioner of its opinion on an interim investigation report.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Council may advise Commissioner of its opinion or recommendation on investigation report

subsection.leadIn: The Council may, in relation to an investigation report submitted under section 17, advise the Commissioner of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its recommendation on the classification of the complaint;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: its recommendation on the Commissioner’s handling or investigation of the complaint;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: its recommendation on any fault or deficiency identified in any practice or procedure adopted by the police force;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: its opinion on the action taken or to be taken in respect of a member of the police force by the Commissioner in connection with the complaint; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: its recommendation on the report other than those mentioned in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c).

subsection.content: If an investigation report is amended in response to the Council’s recommendations referred to in subsection (1), the Commissioner must submit the report as amended to the Council as soon as practicable.
The Council may, if it considers appropriate, submit any part of its opinion or recommendation referred to in subsection (1) to the Chief Executive for consideration.

At any time after an investigation report has been submitted to the Council under section 17, the Council may, for the purpose of considering the report, interview any person who is or may be able to provide information or other assistance to the Council in relation to the report.

At any time after an interim investigation report has been submitted to the Council under section 18, the Council may, with the consent of the Commissioner and for the purpose of considering the report, interview any person who is or may be able to provide information or other assistance to the Council in relation to the report.

Unless the Commissioner is reasonably of the opinion that an interview under subsection (2) would be likely to prejudice the investigation of any crime or any complaint made to him, he must give his consent to the interview.
An interview under this section must be conducted in private.
Subject to subsection (7), the Council may decide who may be present at an interview.
A solicitor or counsel does not have a right of audience before the Council at an interview unless he is the person who is interviewed under this section.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person who is interviewed under this section (that person) is below the age of 16 years, or is known to the Council to be a mentally incapacitated person, that person must be interviewed in the presence of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his parent or guardian;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: such other person as the Council may decide in any particular case.

subsection.content: Despite subsections (5) and (7)(c) but without prejudice to subsection (6), a person interviewed by the Council has the right to be accompanied by his solicitor or counsel at an interview under this section.
The Council must make a record of every interview under section 20, and the record is to be kept for such period as may be necessary for the performance of its functions under this Ordinance.
The record may be used in the circumstances provided for in section 40(2) but not otherwise.

division.name: D3
division.heading: Other Functions relating to Reportable Complaints etc.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Council may require Commissioner to provide information etc. relating to reportable complaints

subsection.leadIn: The Council may require the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to provide any information or material relating to a reportable complaint, including but not limited to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any written statement taken from a person interviewed by a member of the police force in respect of a reportable complaint; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any video recording of the interview; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to clarify any fact, discrepancy or findings relating to a reportable complaint.

subsection.def: In this section, video recording (錄影紀錄) means a recording, on any medium, from which a moving image may by any means be produced and includes the accompanying sound-track.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Council may require Commissioner to investigate reportable complaints

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Council may require the Commissioner to investigate (whether or not there has been any previous investigation) a reportable complaint.

subsection.leadIn: If the reportable complaint is a request for review, then, subject to section 13(3), the Council may require the Commissioner to investigate (whether or not there has been any previous investigation) any matter relating to the request for review only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of the first request for review in respect of a reportable complaint, the request for review is made within 30 days after—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the complainant; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: (where the reportable complaint was made by a person on behalf of the complainant) the person who made the complaint,

paragraph.continued: was notified by the Commissioner of the classification of the reportable complaint;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a second or subsequent request for review in respect of a reportable complaint, the request for review is made within 30 days after—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the complainant; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: (where the last request for review was made by a person on behalf of the complainant) the person who made the last request for review,

paragraph.continued: was notified by the Council of the outcome of the Commissioner’s last review of the classification of the reportable complaint; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a request for review made after the expiry of the period applicable to the request for review under paragraph (a) or (b), the Council is of the opinion that exceptional circumstances exist in relation to the request for review.

subsection.leadIn: In determining whether exceptional circumstances exist for the purposes of subsection (2)(c), the Council may take into account any factor including, but not limited to, the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether there is any fresh evidence in respect of the request for review; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether there are any justifiable reasons for making the request for review after the expiry of the period applicable to the request for review under subsection (2)(a) or (b).

section.name: s24
section.heading: Notification of classification of reportable complaint and result of review

subsection.leadIn: In the case of a reportable complaint that is not a request for review, the Commissioner must notify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the complainant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (where the reportable complaint was made by a person on behalf of the complainant) the person who made the complaint,

subsection.continued: of the classification of the reportable complaint and the reasons for the classification.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of a reportable complaint that is a request for review, the Council must notify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the complainant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (where the reportable complaint was made by a person on behalf of the complainant) the person who made the complaint,

subsection.continued: of the result of the review and the reasons for the result.

subsection.content: Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply where the complainant or the person has indicated to the Commissioner or the Council that he does not wish to be so notified.

subsection.leadIn: In determining the time at which the complainant or the person is notified of such matters as required under subsection (1) or (2), the following provisions apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the notification is left at his address, the notification is effected when it is so left;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the notification is sent by post to his address, the notification is effected when it would in the ordinary course of post be delivered to that address;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the notification is sent by facsimile transmission to his facsimile number, the notification is effected when it would in the ordinary course of such transmission be received at that number; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the notification is sent by electronic mail transmission to his electronic mail address, the notification is effected when it would in the ordinary course of such transmission be received at that address.

subsection.content: In subsection (4), references to his address, his facsimile number or his electronic mail address mean the address, facsimile number or electronic mail address (as the case may be) provided by the complainant or the person to the Commissioner or the Council as a means of contacting him in relation to the reportable complaint.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Members of Council may attend interviews and observe collection of evidence

subsection.leadIn: A member of the Council may at any time and without prior appointment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: attend an interview conducted by the Commissioner in respect of a reportable complaint; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: observe the collection of evidence by the Commissioner in the investigation of a reportable complaint.

subsection.content: Where a member of the Council attends the interview or observes the collection of evidence, sections 37 and 38 apply, with necessary modifications, to that member as if a reference to an observer in those sections were a reference to that member.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Council may require explanation in relation to actions taken etc. in connection with reportable complaints
section.content: The Council may require the Commissioner to provide an explanation in relation to any action taken or to be taken in respect of a member of the police force by the Commissioner in connection with any reportable complaint.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Council may require Commissioner to submit statistics and reports
section.leadIn: The Council may require the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to compile and submit to the Council statistics of the types of conduct of members of the police force that have led to reportable complaints; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to submit to the Council a report on any action taken or to be taken by the Commissioner in respect of a recommendation of the Council made under section 8(1)(a) or (c).

section.name: s28
section.heading: Commissioner to consult Council on orders and manuals relating to handling or investigation of reportable complaints

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner must consult the Council on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proposed new order or manual of the police force that relates to the handling or investigation of reportable complaints; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any significant amendment proposed to be made to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the police general orders made under section 46 of the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the headquarter orders issued under section 47 of that Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the Hong Kong Police Force Procedures Manual; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: any other orders or manuals of the police force,

paragraph.continued: in so far as the amendment relates to the handling or investigation of reportable complaints.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), an amendment is significant if it materially changes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the meaning or interpretation of; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the procedures to be followed under,

subsection.continued: any provision of the order or manual of the police force.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Commissioner to comply with requirements of Council

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding section 4 of the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232), the Commissioner must comply with any requirement made by the Council under this Ordinance unless the Secretary for Security certifies that compliance with the requirement would be likely to prejudice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the security of Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the investigation of any crime.

subsection.content: A certificate signed by the Secretary for Security certifying the matter referred to in subsection (1)(a) or (b) is conclusive evidence as to the matter so certified.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Report to Chief Executive
section.content: The Council may make such reports to the Chief Executive as it thinks necessary.

division.name: D4
division.heading: Council’s Powers relating to its Affairs

section.name: s31
section.heading: Council may charge fees
section.content: The Council may charge reasonable fees for providing copies of, or extracts from, documents or publications of the Council.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Council may hold property, enter into contracts and borrow money
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, the Council may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: acquire, hold and dispose of movable or immovable property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: enter into contracts or other agreements; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: with the approval of the Financial Secretary, borrow money on security or other conditions.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Secretary for Security may appoint such person as he thinks fit to be an observer.

subsection.leadIn: The following persons are not eligible for appointment as observers—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who holds an office of emolument, whether permanent or temporary, in a Government bureau or department;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Secretary-General, the Legal Adviser or any other employee of the Council; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person who was a member of the police force.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Function of observers
section.content: The function of an observer is to assist the Council to observe, in accordance with the provisions of this Part, the manner in which the Commissioner handles or investigates reportable complaints.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Schedule 2 applicable to observers
section.content: Schedule 2 has effect with respect to observers.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Prior notification of interview and collection of evidence

subsection.leadIn: In so far as practicable, the Commissioner must, before he conducts—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an interview in respect of a reportable complaint; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any collection of evidence in the investigation of a reportable complaint,

subsection.continued: notify the Council of the interview or collection of evidence.

subsection.leadIn: The notification must set out—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the nature of the allegations contained in the reportable complaint;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date, time and place of the interview or collection of evidence and the form in which it will be conducted; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the particulars of the interviewee and the interviewer.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner has conducted an interview or any collection of evidence referred to in subsection (1) (the incident) without prior notice to the Council, the Commissioner must, as soon as practicable after the incident and in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notify the Council of the incident;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: explain to the Council the reasons why such prior notice has not been given; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide to the Council information that would have been required to be set out, under subsection (2), in a notification in respect of the interview or collection of evidence if such prior notice had been given.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Observers may attend interviews and observe collection of evidence

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 34, an observer may at any time and without prior appointment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: attend an interview conducted by the Commissioner in respect of a reportable complaint; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: observe the collection of evidence by the Commissioner in the investigation of a reportable complaint.

subsection.leadIn: After having attended the interview or having observed the collection of evidence, the observer must submit a report to the Council stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether, in his opinion, the interview or collection of evidence has been conducted in a fair and impartial manner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where applicable, the particulars of any irregularities detected by the observer in respect of the interview or collection of evidence.

subsection.content: If an observer has an interest (whether directly or indirectly) in a reportable complaint in respect of which an interview or collection of evidence is conducted by the Commissioner, the observer must not attend the interview or observe the collection of evidence.

subsection.leadIn: If, during the interview or collection of evidence, it comes to the knowledge of the observer that he has an interest (whether directly or indirectly) in the reportable complaint, he must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of an interview, disclose the nature of his interest to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the police officer who is designated by the Commissioner to conduct the interview; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the person who is being interviewed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of collection of evidence, disclose the nature of his interest to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the police officer who is designated by the Commissioner to conduct the collection of evidence; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: (if applicable) the person from whom evidence is being collected;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: withdraw from the interview or observation of the collection of evidence (as the case may be); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: report the nature of his interest to the Council.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Council may determine procedures, duty roster, etc. relating to observers

subsection.leadIn: The Council may determine—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the procedure that applies in relation to an observer’s attendance at an interview conducted by the Commissioner in respect of a reportable complaint;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the procedure that applies in relation to an observer’s observation of the collection of evidence by the Commissioner in the investigation of a reportable complaint;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the drawing up of a duty roster of the observers; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any operational matter or arrangement that relates to the performance of the functions of observers under the provisions of this Part.

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, a duty roster under subsection (1)(c) does not affect an observer’s right under section 37(1) to attend an interview or observe the collection of evidence at any time.

part.name: P5
part.heading: Confidentiality and Protection of Council and its Members, etc.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Interpretation of Part 5
section.def: protected information (受保護資料) means matters relating to any complaint that come to a specified person’s actual knowledge in the performance of his functions under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Council;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a member of the Council;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Secretary-General, the Legal Adviser or any other employee of the Council;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person engaged by the Council for his technical or professional services;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: an observer; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a person who at any time had any of the identities described in paragraphs (b), (c), (d) and (e).

subsection.content: Except in the circumstances provided for in subsection (2), a specified person must not disclose any protected information.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not prevent a specified person from disclosing any protected information if the disclosure is necessary—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the performance of his functions under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purpose of reporting evidence of any crime or any suspected crime to such authority as he considers appropriate;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: for the purpose of complying with—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an order of a court; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a requirement in or made under an enactment or any other law,

paragraph.continued: in relation to any criminal, civil or disciplinary proceedings; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for the purpose of complying with a data access request made under section 18 of the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (Cap. 486).

subsection.leadIn: For the avoidance of doubt, in making a disclosure under subsection (2)(a), the Council may disclose to the public—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the facts of any disagreement between the Council and the Commissioner on the findings or classification of a reportable complaint; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: its opinion on the action taken or to be taken in respect of a member of the police force by the Commissioner in connection with a reportable complaint.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), subsection (2)(a) does not authorize the disclosure of the identity of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any complainant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any member of the police force whose conduct is the subject of a complaint; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any person who assists or has assisted the Commissioner in the handling or investigation of a complaint.

subsection.leadIn: A disclosure of any identity referred to in subsection (4)(a), (b) or (c) may be made pursuant to subsection (2)(a) if the disclosure is made to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specified person as defined in section 39 (other than paragraph (f) of that definition);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the complainant;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a person who has written authorization from the complainant—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to make a complaint or request for review on behalf of the complainant (as provided in section 15); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to handle in the complainant’s stead the complaint or request for review made by the complainant;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Commissioner;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a person who assists or has assisted the Commissioner in the handling or investigation of a complaint;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a person whom the Council invites to an interview pursuant to section 20 or any person who is present at an interview in accordance with that section; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the Chief Executive.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Protection of Council and its members, etc.

subsection.content: Any act done, or omitted to be done, by a specified person in good faith in the performance or purported performance of a function under this Ordinance will not render the specified person liable to any civil proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of the law of defamation, if a specified person makes any comment or publishes any matter in relation to a complaint—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in any communication, report or statement, in writing or otherwise; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the performance of his functions under this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: that comment or publication is absolutely privileged.

subsection.content: The protection given by subsection (1) or (2) does not apply to a specified person within the meaning of paragraph (d) of the definition of specified person in section 39.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Interpretation of Part 6
section.def: *commencement date (生效日期) means the date of commencement of this Ordinance;
former Council (前警監會) means the Independent Police Complaints Council existing immediately before the commencement date;
former observer (前觀察員) means a person who was an observer under the scheme known as the Independent Police Complaints Council observers scheme existing immediately before the commencement date.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Continuance of things done by former Council

subsection.content: The enactment of this Ordinance does not affect the validity of anything done by, in relation to or on behalf of the former Council before the commencement date*.

Anything done before the commencement date by, in relation to or on behalf of the former Council pursuant to or in connection with its functions has effect as from that date as if done by, in relation to or on behalf of the Council.

Anything that, immediately before the commencement date, is in the process of being done by, in relation to or on behalf of the former Council pursuant to or in connection with its functions may, as from that date, be continued by, in relation to or on behalf of the Council to the extent that it is consistent with this Ordinance.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Pre-existing legal claims
section.leadIn: Without limiting section 43, a legal claim (including any judicial and administrative proceedings)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by or against the former Council; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: existing immediately before the commencement date*,

section.continued: does not abate by reason of the commencement of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), a person who, immediately before the commencement date*—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: holds an appointment as the Chairman, a Vice-Chairman or any other member of the former Council; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is a former observer,

subsection.continued: continues to be, as from that date, the Chairman, a Vice-Chairman or such other member of the Council or an observer (as the case may be) as if he were appointed under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: The person in subsection (1) continues to hold his appointment only for the unexpired term under his previous appointment, but is eligible for reappointment under section 1(b) or 2(b) of Schedule 1 or section 1(b) of Schedule 2 (as the case may be).

A person who, immediately before the commencement date, is the Secretary or the Legal Adviser of the former Council continues to be, as from that date until the Secretary-General or the Legal Adviser (as the case may be) has been appointed under section 6(1), the Secretary-General or the Legal Adviser (as the case may be) of the Council on the same terms and conditions as those applicable to that person immediately before that date.

A person who, immediately before the commencement date, is an officer (other than the Secretary and the Legal Adviser) of the former Council continues to be, as from that date until such time as the Council and the Government may agree, such officer of the Council on the same terms and conditions as those applicable to that person immediately before that date.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Lists submitted to former Council

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the first list of reportable complaints submitted under section 9(1)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the first list of notifiable complaints submitted under section 9(1)(b),

section.continued: the last list containing the corresponding information that was submitted by the Commissioner to the former Council before the commencement date* is to be regarded as—

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the last list of reportable complaints for the purposes of section 9(2); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the last list of notifiable complaints for the purposes of section 9(3),

schedule.name: sch1
schedule.heading: Provisions with respect to Members, Proceedings, Committees and Finances of, and Execution of Documents by, and Other Miscellaneous Matters of, Council

section.name: s1
section.heading: Term of office of Chairman
section.leadIn: The Chairman (other than a person appointed under section 5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be appointed for a term not exceeding 3 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is eligible for reappointment for a further term or terms not exceeding 3 years each.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Term of office of Vice-Chairmen and appointed members
section.leadIn: A Vice-Chairman or an appointed member (other than a person appointed under section 5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be appointed for a term not exceeding 2 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is eligible for reappointment for a further term or terms not exceeding 2 years each.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Resignation of Chairman, Vice-Chairmen and appointed members

subsection.content: The Chairman, a Vice-Chairman or an appointed member may resign from office by giving notice in writing to the Chief Executive.
The resignation under subsection (1) takes effect on the date the Chief Executive receives the notice or the date specified in the notice (whichever is the later).

section.name: s4
section.heading: Removal of Chairman, Vice-Chairmen and appointed members
section.content: The Chief Executive may by notice in writing remove the Chairman, a Vice-Chairman or an appointed member from office if the Chief Executive is satisfied that the Chairman, Vice-Chairman or appointed member (as the case may be) is unable or unfit to perform his functions due to permanent incapacity or other sufficient cause.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Acting appointment
section.leadIn: The Chief Executive may appoint any person to act as the Chairman, a Vice-Chairman or an appointed member if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chairman, Vice-Chairman or appointed member (as the case may be) is precluded by illness, absence from Hong Kong or any other cause from performing his functions; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the office of the Chairman, Vice-Chairman or appointed member (as the case may be) is vacant pending a new appointment or reappointment.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Fees and allowances to Chairman, Vice-Chairmen and appointed members
section.content: The Council may pay the Chairman, Vice-Chairmen and appointed members such fees and allowances as the Chief Executive may determine.

subsection.content: The Council is to have a common seal.
The common seal may be affixed to a document only if authorized by a resolution of the Council.
The affixing of the common seal is to be authenticated by the signatures of any 2 members of the Council authorized by the Council, either generally or specially in that behalf.
A document purporting to be duly executed under the common seal is to be regarded as having been duly executed unless the contrary is proved.

Any contract or instrument which, if entered into or executed by a natural person, would not be required to be entered into or executed under seal, may be entered into or executed on behalf of the Council by any of its members, the Secretary-General, the Legal Adviser or any other employee of the Council generally or specially authorized by the Council in that behalf.
The Council is to meet as often as is necessary for the purpose of performing its functions.
The Chairman may appoint the time and place for the Council to meet.
The Council may, by its procedure determined under section 16, make provisions for a Vice-Chairman to appoint, in the absence of the Chairman, the time and place for the Council to meet.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Quorum for Council meetings
section.content: The quorum for a meeting of the Council is 6 members of the Council.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Chairman to preside at Council meetings

subsection.content: The Chairman must preside at a meeting of the Council.
If the Chairman is absent or vacates the chair, a Vice-Chairman elected by the appointed members present must preside at the meeting.
If neither the Chairman nor the 3 Vice-Chairmen can preside at the meeting, an appointed member elected from amongst the appointed members present must preside at the meeting.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Determination of matters at Council meetings

subsection.content: A matter for determination at a meeting of the Council must be decided by a majority of the votes of the members of the Council present and voting on that matter.
If there is an equality of votes, the person presiding at the meeting has a casting vote in addition to his original vote.
Subject to subsection (5), anything that may be done at a meeting of the Council may be done by circulation of papers to all members of the Council without a meeting.

Subject to subsection (5), a written resolution that is approved by a majority of all members of the Council is as valid and effectual as if it had been passed at a meeting of the Council by the votes of the members so approving.

If any member of the Council requests by notice in writing addressed to the Secretary-General that a matter referred to in the papers circulated under subsection (3) be determined at a meeting of the Council, the matter must be so determined.

For the avoidance of doubt, a reference to circulation of papers in this section includes circulation of information by electronic means, and a reference to the papers in this section must be construed accordingly.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Disclosure of interest in reportable complaints and notifiable complaints

subsection.leadIn: If a member of the Council has an interest (whether directly or indirectly) in a reportable complaint or a notifiable complaint being discussed or to be discussed at a meeting of the Council, the member—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must disclose the nature of his interest at or before the meeting;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must withdraw from the meeting during the discussion of the complaint;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must not vote on a resolution concerning the complaint; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must not be counted for the purpose of forming a quorum.

subsection.content: If the disclosure is made by the member presiding at the meeting, the member must vacate the chair during the discussion of the complaint.

When the member vacates his chair under subsection (2), the other members present at the meeting must appoint, by a majority, one of their number to preside at the meeting when the chair is so vacated.
In this section, a reference to a reportable complaint or a notifiable complaint includes any matter that is related to the complaint.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Disclosure of interest in matters other than reportable complaints and notifiable complaints

subsection.leadIn: If a member of the Council has an interest (whether directly or indirectly) in a matter (the Matter) being discussed or to be discussed at a meeting of the Council and the Matter is neither a reportable complaint (including related matter) nor a notifiable complaint (including related matter), then the member—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must disclose the nature of his interest at or before the meeting;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: except as otherwise determined by a majority of the other members present at the meeting—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must not vote on a resolution concerning the Matter; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: must not be counted for the purpose of forming a quorum.

subsection.content: If the disclosure is made by the member presiding at the meeting, the member must, if so required by a majority of the other members present at the meeting, vacate the chair during the discussion of the Matter.

If the member is required to vacate his chair under subsection (2), the other members present at the meeting must appoint, by a majority, one of their number to preside at the meeting when the chair is so vacated.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Disclosure of interest in cases of written resolutions
section.leadIn: In the case of a written resolution on a matter in which a member of the Council has an interest (whether directly or indirectly)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must state the nature of his interest in the papers being circulated; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: must return the papers with his interest so stated to the Secretary-General; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must not vote on the written resolution; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: must not be counted in calculating a majority for the approval of the written resolution.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Disclosure of interest be recorded
section.content: A disclosure made under section 12(1)(a), 13(1)(a) or 14(a) must be recorded by the Council.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Council may determine its own procedure
section.content: Subject to the other provisions of this Ordinance, the Council may determine its own procedure.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Establishment of committees
section.content: The Council may from amongst its members establish committees, panels or sub-groups to assist the Council in the performance of any of its functions under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: The chairman of a committee must be elected from amongst its members.
The chairman of a committee must preside at a meeting of the committee.
If the chairman of a committee is absent or vacates the chair, a member of the committee elected from amongst the members of the committee present must preside at the meeting.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Determination of matters at committee meetings

subsection.content: A matter for determination at a meeting of a committee must be decided by a majority of the votes of the members of the committee present and voting on that matter.
If there is an equality of votes, the person presiding at the meeting has a casting vote in addition to his original vote.
Subject to subsection (5), anything that may be done at a meeting of a committee may be done by circulation of papers to all members of the committee without a meeting.

Subject to subsection (5), a written resolution that is approved by a majority of all members of a committee is as valid and effectual as if it had been passed at a meeting of the committee by the votes of the members so approving.

If any member of a committee requests by notice in writing addressed to the Secretary-General that a matter referred to in the papers circulated under subsection (3) be determined at a meeting of the committee, the matter must be so determined.

For the avoidance of doubt, a reference to circulation of papers in this section includes circulation of information by electronic means, and a reference to the papers in this section must be construed accordingly.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Disclosure of interest in reportable complaints and notifiable complaints

subsection.leadIn: If a member of a committee has an interest (whether directly or indirectly) in a reportable complaint or a notifiable complaint being discussed or to be discussed at a meeting of the committee, the member—

subparagraph.name: a
subparagraph.content: must disclose the nature of his interest at or before the meeting;

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: must withdraw from the meeting during the discussion of the complaint;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: must not vote on a resolution concerning the complaint; and

subparagraph.name: d
subparagraph.content: must not be counted for the purpose of forming a quorum.

subsection.content: If the disclosure is made by the member presiding at the meeting, the member must vacate the chair during the discussion of the complaint.

When the member vacates his chair under subsection (2), the other members present at the meeting must appoint, by a majority, one of their number to preside at the meeting when the chair is so vacated.
In this section, a reference to a reportable complaint or a notifiable complaint includes any matter that is related to the complaint.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Disclosure of interest in matters other than reportable complaints and notifiable complaints

subsection.leadIn: If a member of a committee has an interest (whether directly or indirectly) in a matter (the Matter) being discussed or to be discussed at a meeting of the committee and the Matter is neither a reportable complaint (including related matter) nor a notifiable complaint (including related matter), then the member—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must disclose the nature of his interest at or before the meeting;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: except as otherwise determined by a majority of the other members present at the meeting—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must not vote on a resolution concerning the Matter; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: must not be counted for the purpose of forming a quorum.

subsection.content: If the disclosure is made by the member presiding at the meeting, the member must, if so required by a majority of the other members present at the meeting, vacate the chair during the discussion of the Matter.

If the member is required to vacate his chair under subsection (2), the other members present at the meeting must appoint, by a majority, one of their number to preside at the meeting when the chair is so vacated.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Disclosure of interest in cases of written resolutions
section.leadIn: In the case of a written resolution on a matter in which a member of a committee has an interest (whether directly or indirectly)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must state the nature of his interest in the papers being circulated; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: must return the papers with his interest so stated to the Secretary-General; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must not vote on the written resolution; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: must not be counted in calculating a majority for the approval of the written resolution.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Disclosure of interest be recorded
section.content: A disclosure made under section 20(1)(a), 21(1)(a) or 22(a) must be recorded by the committee.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Committee may determine its own procedure
section.content: Subject to the other provisions of this Ordinance, each committee may determine its own procedure.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Resources of Council
section.leadIn: The resources of the Council consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all money paid by the Government to the Council and appropriated for that purpose by the Legislative Council; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all other money and property, including fees, gifts, donations, interest and accumulations of income, received by the Council.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Council may invest money that is not immediately required to be expended.
The Council must not invest money except in such form of investment as the Financial Secretary approves.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Financial year
section.leadIn: The financial year of the Council is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period beginning on the date of commencement* of this Ordinance and ending on 31 March in the next following year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period of 12 months ending on 31 March in each subsequent year.

subsection.content: The Council must keep proper accounts of its financial transactions.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the end of a financial year of the Council, the Council must prepare—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement of accounts for that financial year containing an income and expenditure account and a cash flow statement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a balance sheet showing the financial position of the Council as at the end of that financial year.

subsection.content: The Council must appoint as its auditor a person who is a certified public accountant (practising) as defined by section 2(1) of the Accounting and Financial Reporting Council Ordinance (Cap. 588). (Amended L.N. 66 of 2022)

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the end of a financial year of the Council, the auditor must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: audit the accounts and the statement of accounts prepared by the Council for that financial year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: submit to the Council a report on the statement of accounts.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable and in any case not later than 6 months after the end of a financial year of the Council, or such further period (as may be reasonable in the circumstances) as the Chief Executive may allow, the Council must submit to the Chief Executive—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a report on the performance of the Council’s functions under this Ordinance during that financial year;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of the statement of accounts prepared by the Council for that financial year; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a copy of the auditor’s report on the statement of accounts prepared by the Council that is submitted to the Council under section 29(2).

subsection.content: The Council must cause the documents referred to in subsection (1) to be tabled in the Legislative Council as soon as practicable after receiving the Chief Executive’s approval for tabling.

The Director of Audit may, in respect of any financial year of the Council, conduct an examination into the economy, efficiency and effectiveness with which the Council has expended its resources in performing its functions.

subsection.leadIn: The Director of Audit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has a right of access at all reasonable times to all such records, books, vouchers, documents, cash, receipts, stamps, securities, stores and any other property in the custody or under the control of the Council as he may reasonably require for the purpose of conducting an examination under this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is entitled to require from any person who holds or is accountable for any such document or materials such information and explanation as he considers reasonably necessary for that purpose.

subsection.content: The Director of Audit may report to the President of the Legislative Council the results of an examination conducted by him under this section.
Subsection (1) does not entitle the Director of Audit to question the merits of the policy objectives of the Council.

The Council may delegate in writing any of its functions under this Ordinance to a committee, a member of the Council, the Secretary-General, the Legal Adviser or any other employee of the Council, but a function specified in subsection (6) may not be so delegated.
A delegation under this section may be general or limited and may be subject to conditions.
The Council may, at any time, amend or revoke a delegation made under this section.
A delegate of the Council under this section is presumed to be acting in accordance with the terms of the relevant delegation in the absence of evidence to the contrary.
A delegated function may be performed by the Council despite the delegation.

subsection.leadIn: The functions that the Council may not delegate under subsection (1) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the power to delegate under that subsection;

section.name: s33
section.heading: Exemption from taxation
section.content: The Council is exempt from taxation under the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112).

subsection.content: An observer may resign from office by giving notice in writing to the Secretary for Security.
The resignation under subsection (1) takes effect on the date the Secretary for Security receives the notice or the date specified in the notice (whichever is the later).

section.name: s3
section.heading: Removal of observers
section.content: The Secretary for Security may by notice in writing remove an observer from office if the Secretary for Security is satisfied that the observer is unable or unfit to perform his functions due to permanent incapacity or other sufficient cause.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Fees and allowances to observers
section.content: The Council may pay the observers such fees and allowances as the Secretary for Security approves.
